hints.content:
An $\blueE{\text{even}}$ number is a number that can be split into $2$ equal groups.

We find $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers by making sure every object in the group has a pair.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9d50cd961bb1ee962eb60cc708a5e737e9d4486c)

Examples of $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers are $\blueE2, \blueE4,\blueE6, \blueE8, \blueE{10},  . .  .$

An $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number **cannot** be split into $2$ equal groups. 

We find $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers by trying to pair objects and finding there is **not** always a pair.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/10c3af09ebfcd0c6d05b4edd219f33894cc4d8b9)

Examples of $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers are $\maroonD1, \maroonD3, \maroonD5, \maroonD7, \maroonD9, . . . $

In this image, there are $\maroonD{5}$ beavers.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/f2f6f962daf95c5b7f4e41a793d84a8483806873)

Each beaver does **not** have a pair, so there are an odd number of beavers.

In this image, there are $\blueE{2}$ penguins.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/0d4e57036d7c1359d14868d7202d96630659a1a3)

The $2$ penguins make a pair, so there is an even number of penguins.

In this image, there are $\blueE{8}$ turtles.

![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/3e35affa405622519a501f7e78216a79baed15dc)

Each turtle has a pair, so there are an even number of turtles.

Here is the completed table:

Image | Even/Odd
- | - | -
![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/7d10cd5726b473616a74d09cb5dd50fcc23a6693) | **Odd**
![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/0d4e57036d7c1359d14868d7202d96630659a1a3) | **Even**
![](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/0721c0dbb7a394584a1e6df76a8520446939cf29)  | **Even**

question.content:
**Determine whether the number of objects is even or odd.**
